Back:
ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: Ever wore a costume at a party and pretended to be someone else? Type assertion lets variables do that in code!

ğŸ“– Definition: Type assertion tells the compiler: 'Trust me, I know the actual type of this variable.' It's a way to override TypeScript's type inference.

ğŸ”§ Syntax: value as Type or <Type>value

ğŸŒ Example: const result = kgToGm(1000) as number;

ğŸ”® Analogy: Like showing your ID at a club â€” you're asserting your 'type' to gain access!

ğŸ”¥ Emotional Hook: Imagine a magic box that can hold anything â€” a toy, a phone, or a pizza! Thatâ€™s what any is in TypeScript.

ğŸ“– Definition: any allows a variable to be assigned any type â€” bypassing TypeScript's type checking.

âš ï¸ Caveat: Overusing any defeats the purpose of using TypeScript!

ğŸŒ Example:
let anything: any;
anything = 123;
anything = 'hello';

ğŸ”® Analogy: Like using a drawer labeled 'miscellaneous' â€” useful but messy.

ğŸ’¥ Emotional Hook: Ever ordered a meal where you could pick rice or bread? Union types are like flexible menus in code!

ğŸ“– Definition: Union types allow a variable or parameter to hold more than one type, using the | symbol.

ğŸŒ Example: (value: string | number) means value can be either a string or number.

ğŸ”® Analogy: Like saying: 'Bring me tea or coffee â€” I'm good with either!'

ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: Picture a detective who checks clues to identify a suspect. typeof helps TypeScript narrow down what a variable really is.

ğŸ“– Definition: Type narrowing is when you write code that checks a variable's type to safely access its properties.

ğŸŒ Example:
if (typeof value === 'string') {...}

ğŸ”® Analogy: Like asking: 'Is this a key or a pen?' before using it properly.

ğŸ’¡ Emotional Hook: Imagine a vending machine that sometimes gives snacks, sometimes gives change. Thatâ€™s a function with flexible return types!

ğŸ“– Example: kgToGm(value: string | number): string | number

ğŸŒ What it does: Converts kilograms to grams and returns a string or number depending on input type.

ğŸ”® Analogy: Like a smart translator who can speak in your language or theirs depending on what you ask.

Front: âš ï¸ Custom Error Typing in Try-Catch
Back:
ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: What if you could catch errors and still know exactly what type of problem it was? That's what typed errors do.

ğŸ“– Use: You can assert the type of caught errors using as.

ğŸŒ Example:
catch (error) { console.log((error as CustomError).message); }

ğŸ”® Analogy: Like having a first-aid kit labeled with what kind of injury itâ€™s for â€” makes treating it easier!
Back

ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: Two tools â€” same mission, different strengths!

ğŸ“– Type: Used for defining any kind of type (objects, unions, tuples, functions).
ğŸ“– Interface: Focused on describing the **shape of objects**.

ğŸŒ Example:
type A = { name: string }
interface B { name: string }

ğŸ”® Analogy: Type is a **Swiss Army Knife**, Interface is a **blueprint**.

ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: Like a child inheriting from a parent!

ğŸ“– Syntax: interface C extends A { role: string }

ğŸŒ Example:
interface UserWithRole extends User { role: string }

ğŸ”® Analogy: Like making a copy of a base contract and adding more terms.

ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: Merging two paths into one journey!

ğŸ“– Syntax: type C = A & { role: string }

ğŸŒ Example:
type UserWithRole = User & { role: string }

ğŸ”® Analogy: Like combining two Lego sets into a bigger creation.

ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: Arrays are just objects with numbered keys!

ğŸ“– Type: type Roll = number[]
ğŸ“– Interface: interface Roll { [index: number]: number }

ğŸŒ Example:
const roll: Roll = [1, 2, 3];

ğŸ”® Analogy: Like lockers labeled 0, 1, 2 storing numbers.

ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: Math formulas as types!

ğŸ“– Syntax: type Add = (a: number, b: number) => number

ğŸ”® Analogy: Like labeling your calculator with specific input/output.

ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: Interfaces can describe callable shapes too!

ğŸ“– Syntax: interface Add { (a: number, b: number): number }

ğŸ”® Analogy: Like a remote that only accepts two batteries and gives you a result.

Front: ğŸ§  When to Use Type vs Interface?
Back:
ğŸ›  Use type:
- When working with unions, intersections, tuples, primitives.
ğŸ— Use interface:
- When describing object shapes or needing OOP-style inheritance.

âœ… Pro Tip: Interfaces are best for public APIs or class-like structures.

ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: Why copy-paste when you can reuse with type safety?

ğŸ“– Definition: Generics let you define a placeholder (like <T>) that can be replaced by any type.

ğŸ§  Syntax: type Box<T> = T[];

ğŸ”® Analogy: Like a lunch box that can carry rice, bread, or fruit depending on the day.

ğŸ§  Syntax: type GenericArray<T> = Array<T>;

GenericArray<number> â†’ [1, 2, 3]

ğŸ”® Analogy: Like a vending machine that accepts different items based on customer choice.

ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: A list of people â€” all checked for correct structure!

ğŸ§  Benefit: Strong typing across all elements, no surprises.

ğŸ§  Syntax: type Pair<X, Y> = [X, Y];

[Persian"
column6:
User>

Back:

ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: Build a blueprint once, reuse forever â€” for any data type!

interface Box<T> { item: T }

ğŸ“¦ Example: Developer<T, X = null> means T and X are placeholder types.

ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: Give your API smart defaults!

If the second type isnâ€™t passed, it defaults to null.

Front: âŒš Using Generic Interface with Custom Type
Back:
ğŸ“¦ Example:
Developer<EmilabWatch> means T = EmilabWatch, X = null

ğŸ’¡ Tip: Strongly typed nested objects improve maintainability.

Developer<T, X> is like:
- A developer with a smartwatch of type T

ğŸ”® Analogy: Imagine building a 'Developer Profile' form that works for any brand of smartwatch or bike. Generics give you that flexibility!

ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: Future-proof your data structures.

âœ… Benefits:
- Reusability

ğŸ“Œ Use when: Youâ€™re building flexible APIs or object structures.

ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: Write once, use forever â€” with any type!

ğŸ§  Syntax:

âœ… Benefit: Strong typing + flexibility = scalable code.

ğŸ“¦ Example:

ğŸ§  Concept: Use angle brackets to specify types.

Front: ğŸš« What problem do constraints solve in generic functions?
Back:
They make sure that generic types have the required properties.

ğŸ§  Example:
<T extends { id: number }> ensures T has at least an id.

const addCourseToStudent = <T extends { id: number; name: string; email: string }>(student: T) => { ... }

âœ… This ensures any student has id, name, and email.

Front: ğŸ§ª Can you pass extra properties with constraint?
Back:
Yes! As long as the required fields exist.

emni or devType are allowed because they don't violate the structure.

Front: ğŸ§© How to use custom types with constraints?
Back:
You can pass inline types or reusable ones:
addCourseToStudent<{id:number, name:string, email:string, devType:string}>({...})
or use a defined interface Student.

Front: ğŸ Analogy: What is a generic constraint like?
Back:
Like a job application ğŸ“„ that says: 'Must have Name, ID, and Email.'
Anything extra (skills, experience) is fine, but missing a required field? âŒ Rejected!

- Type safety
- Prevent runtime errors

- Make code more readable and maintainable
